elements.content: Six coordination polymers were prepared by linking Mn(SCN)2 units by three different bis(4-pyridyl) substituited hydrazone derivatives (L) in three different solvents (methanol, ethanol, and acetonitrile) in order to study the effect of the hydrogen bonding ability of L on the formation of solvates rather than interpenetrated solvent-free interpenetrated structures. When the ligand L which cannot act as a hydrogen donor was used, in all three solvents the same product was obtained. This was a [Mn(SCN)2 L 2] n metal–organic framework, consisting of two-dimensional (2D) networks, each interpenetrating two neighboring ones. When the bridging ligands L have additional functional groups capable of acting as hydrogen donors or acceptors, synthesis from acetonitrile yields non-interpenetrating 2D [Mn(SCN)2 L 2] n networks with solvent molecules occupying the voids of the network. Other solvents were found to yield interpenetrated solvent free networks, or they replaced some of the L ligands, forming one-dimensional coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text: Six coordination polymers were prepared by linking Mn(SCN)2 units by three different bis(4-pyridyl) substituited hydrazone derivatives (L) in three different solvents (methanol, ethanol, and acetonitrile) in order to study the effect of the hydrogen bonding ability of L on the formation of solvates rather than interpenetrated solvent-free interpenetrated structures. When the ligand L which cannot act as a hydrogen donor was used, in all three solvents the same product was obtained. This was a [Mn(SCN)2 L 2] n  metal-organic framework, consisting of two-dimensional (2D) networks, each interpenetrating two neighboring ones. When the bridging ligands L have additional functional groups capable of acting as hydrogen donors or acceptors, synthesis from acetonitrile yields non-interpenetrating 2D [Mn(SCN)2 L 2] n  networks with solvent molecules occupying the voids of the network. Other solvents were found to yield interpenetrated solvent free networks, or they replaced some of the L ligands, forming one-dimensional coordination polymers.

elements.content: In a series of [Mn(SCN)2 L 2] n two-dimensional networks with different bis(4-pyridyl) substituited hydrazones L, the interpenetration of [Mn(SCN)2 L 2] n sheets is controlled by the hydrogen bonding ability of L. When L forms hydrogen bonds, it is usually with solvent molecules which either enter the voids of the networks preventing interpenetration or coordinate Mn, disrupting [Mn(SCN)2 L 2] n networks, or else solvent free interpenetrated structures are formed.
elements.clean_text: In a series of [Mn(SCN)2 L 2] n  two-dimensional networks with different bis(4-pyridyl) substituited hydrazones L, the interpenetration of [Mn(SCN)2 L 2] n  sheets is controlled by the hydrogen bonding ability of L. When L forms hydrogen bonds, it is usually with solvent molecules which either enter the voids of the networks preventing interpenetration or coordinate Mn, disrupting [Mn(SCN)2 L 2] n  networks, or else solvent free interpenetrated structures are formed.

elements.content: The research of synthesis and properties of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) is among the most rapidly developing areas in materials chemistry today due to their potential as functional materials in gas storage and separation, catalysis, as chemical sensors, in drug delivery, and many others. Most of these potential and actual applications are based on the high and permanent porosity of these materials, with pore sizes ranging from several angstroms to over 10 nm, which in turn also leads to high specific surfaces and high absorptivity. However, structures with large voids are inherently unstable, and upon their formation, the porosity of the system is often reduced by interpenetration of one (or several) frameworks through another. Such interpenetrated structures are polymeric analogues of catenanes and rotaxanesalthough there is no covalent bonding between the interpenetrated networks, they cannot be separated without the destruction of the entire network. An alternative way a structure with large voids is stabilized is by the inclusion of solvent molecules. In such materials, the solvent can often be subsequently removed or replaced, rendering them functional porous materials.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The research of synthesis and properties of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) is among the most rapidly developing areas in materials chemistry today due to their potential as functional materials in gas storage and separation, catalysis, as chemical sensors, in drug delivery, and many others. Most of these potential and actual applications are based on the high and permanent porosity of these materials, with pore sizes ranging from several angstroms to over 10 nm, which in turn also leads to high specific surfaces and high absorptivity. However, structures with large voids are inherently unstable, and upon their formation, the porosity of the system is often reduced by interpenetration of one (or several) frameworks through another. Such interpenetrated structures are polymeric analogues of catenanes and rotaxanesalthough there is no covalent bonding between the interpenetrated networks, they cannot be separated without the destruction of the entire network. An alternative way a structure with large voids is stabilized is by the inclusion of solvent molecules. In such materials, the solvent can often be subsequently removed or replaced, rendering them functional porous materials.

elements.content: A key question in the design of functional MOFs is therefore the one of controlling (or avoiding) the formation of interpenetrated structures. There are a number of methods that have shown some success in suppressing the interpenetration in MOFs, and these include modification of reaction conditions, the use of templates, use of flexible ligands, and modification of ligands. The latter approach has for the most part been based on the use of ligands with bulky substituents, as such substituents that can fill the voids of the structure thus both stabilizing the structure by making it more closely packed and making the remaining space insufficient for a second network. A most inspiring application of this approach was demonstrated using bridging ligands with bulky side chains which can be thermally or photolytically removed after the creation of the MOF. Thus, non-interpenetrated structures can be easily achieved, and the subsequent removal of the bulky substituents can produce a structure with large voids.
elements.clean_text: A key question in the design of functional MOFs is therefore the one of controlling (or avoiding) the formation of interpenetrated structures. There are a number of methods that have shown some success in suppressing the interpenetration in MOFs, and these include modification of reaction conditions, the use of templates, use of flexible ligands, and modification of ligands. The latter approach has for the most part been based on the use of ligands with bulky substituents, as such substituents that can fill the voids of the structure thus both stabilizing the structure by making it more closely packed and making the remaining space insufficient for a second network. A most inspiring application of this approach was demonstrated using bridging ligands with bulky side chains which can be thermally or photolytically removed after the creation of the MOF. Thus, non-interpenetrated structures can be easily achieved, and the subsequent removal of the bulky substituents can produce a structure with large voids.

elements.content: There are numerous examples where solvent molecules were found to produce a dramatic effect on the extended structure of the network by acting as a template for the assembly (or an additional ligand). This points to an interesting potential method of MOF design by combining the ligand modification approach with the possibilities of supramolecular control of MOF interpenetration. Addition of hydrogen bond donor or acceptor groups on the bridging ligands can lead to hydrogen bonding with the solvent molecules and thus to increased probability that the voids in the structure will be filled with solvent molecules, precluding interpenetration. Furthermore, placing specific hydrogen bond donor and acceptor sets on the ligands could be useful for increasing the specificity of binding of different solvent molecules, which can in turn act as templates for different MOF topologies and/or entanglements.
elements.clean_text: There are numerous examples where solvent molecules were found to produce a dramatic effect on the extended structure of the network by acting as a template for the assembly (or an additional ligand). This points to an interesting potential method of MOF design by combining the ligand modification approach with the possibilities of supramolecular control of MOF interpenetration. Addition of hydrogen bond donor or acceptor groups on the bridging ligands can lead to hydrogen bonding with the solvent molecules and thus to increased probability that the voids in the structure will be filled with solvent molecules, precluding interpenetration. Furthermore, placing specific hydrogen bond donor and acceptor sets on the ligands could be useful for increasing the specificity of binding of different solvent molecules, which can in turn act as templates for different MOF topologies and/or entanglements.

elements.content: Herein we report a study of MOFs based on Mn(NCS)2 units linked by bis(4-pyridyl) substituted hydrazone derivatives. The selected hydrazone ligands (Scheme ) are relatively conformationally flexible building blocks, which can adopt different conformations with respect to the relative orientations of the carbonyl, amide N–H, and methyl groups. Also, the three ligands differ in their hydrogen bonding ability, with L1 without potential hydrogen donor or acceptor groups, while L2 and L3, where the linkers between the two pyridyl groups are secondary amides, can form hydrogen bonds with neighboring molecules both as hydrogen donors and as hydrogen acceptors. The MOFs with all three ligands were then prepared from three different solventsacetonitrile (MeCN), a hydrogen acceptor, as well as methanol (MeOH) and ethanol (EtOH), which can act both as hydrogen donors and hydrogen acceptorsin order to examine how the hydrogen bonding between the ligands and the solvent molecules would affect the interpenetration of MOF networks.
elements.clean_text: Herein we report a study of MOFs based on Mn(NCS)2 units linked by bis(4-pyridyl) substituted hydrazone derivatives. The selected hydrazone ligands (Scheme ) are relatively conformationally flexible building blocks, which can adopt different conformations with respect to the relative orientations of the carbonyl, amide N-H, and methyl groups. Also, the three ligands differ in their hydrogen bonding ability, with L1 without potential hydrogen donor or acceptor groups, while L2 and L3, where the linkers between the two pyridyl groups are secondary amides, can form hydrogen bonds with neighboring molecules both as hydrogen donors and as hydrogen acceptors. The MOFs with all three ligands were then prepared from three different solventsacetonitrile (MeCN), a hydrogen acceptor, as well as methanol (MeOH) and ethanol (EtOH), which can act both as hydrogen donors and hydrogen acceptorsin order to examine how the hydrogen bonding between the ligands and the solvent molecules would affect the interpenetration of MOF networks.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<caption>
<title>Molecular Diagrams
of the Organic Ligands Used in This Study</title>
</caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="cg-2014-01741r_0001.tif"></graphic>
</fig>
elements.clean_text: 1  Molecular Diagrams of the Organic Ligands Used in This Study

elements.content: Using the classical bridging ligand L1 which lacks potential hydrogen donor or acceptor groups (except the very weakly basic imine nitrogen atom which is only a modest hydrogen acceptor and often does not participate in intermolecular hydrogen bonding) yields complex 1 in all three tested solvents. 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic system, space group Pbcn, with a Mn(II) ion, two L1 ligands, and two coordinating NCS– anions in the asymmetric unit. The overall coordination geometry of the Mn(II) ion in 1 can be described as a distorted octahedron consisting of four NPy donors from four different ligands and two N atoms from two independent NCS– anions. The pyridyl ligands coordinate in an equatorial fashion, with the axial positions occupied by monodentate N-bound thiocyanate anions. The overall molecular structure is therefore a two-dimensional (2D) [Mn(NCS)2 L1 2] n network of (4,4) topology (Figure a) perpendicular to the crystallographic a axis. The dimensions of the voids in the 2D network are ca. 13 × 13 Å2 and are occupied by atoms of two parallel neighboring networks, thus leading to a structure where each 2D network interpenetrates with two neighboring ones (Figure b). This 3-fold parallel interpenetration is enabled by the fact that the [Mn(NCS)2 L 2] n networks are corrugated, with Mn atoms alternatively placed as much as 4.5 Å above and below the mean plane of the network. The interpenetration results in layers of triply interpenetrating sheets lying in the bc plane which stack along the a axis, with only weak hydrogen bonding contacts (C–H···N, C–H···S, and C–H···π) between the networks.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Using the classical bridging ligand L1  which lacks potential hydrogen donor or acceptor groups (except the very weakly basic imine nitrogen atom which is only a modest hydrogen acceptor and often does not participate in intermolecular hydrogen bonding) yields complex 1 in all three tested solvents. 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic system, space group Pbcn, with a Mn(II) ion, two L1 ligands, and two coordinating NCS- anions in the asymmetric unit. The overall coordination geometry of the Mn(II) ion in 1 can be described as a distorted octahedron consisting of four NPy donors from four different ligands and two N atoms from two independent NCS- anions. The pyridyl ligands coordinate in an equatorial fashion, with the axial positions occupied by monodentate N-bound thiocyanate anions. The overall molecular structure is therefore a two-dimensional (2D) [Mn(NCS)2 L1 2] n  network of (4,4) topology (Figure a) perpendicular to the crystallographic a axis. The dimensions of the voids in the 2D network are ca. 13 × 13 Å2 and are occupied by atoms of two parallel neighboring networks, thus leading to a structure where each 2D network interpenetrates with two neighboring ones (Figure b). This 3-fold parallel interpenetration is enabled by the fact that the [Mn(NCS)2 L 2] n  networks are corrugated, with Mn atoms alternatively placed as much as 4.5 Å above and below the mean plane of the network. The interpenetration results in layers of triply interpenetrating sheets lying in the bc plane which stack along the a axis, with only weak hydrogen bonding contacts (C-H⋅⋅⋅N, C-H⋅⋅⋅S, and C-H⋅⋅⋅π) between the networks.

elements.content: (a) A single 2D (4,4) sheet in the structure of 1; (b) interpenetration of three neighboring parallel [Mn(NCS)2 L1 2] n networks in 1.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) A single 2D (4,4) sheet in the structure of 1; (b) interpenetration of three neighboring parallel [Mn(NCS)2 L1 2] n  networks in 1.

elements.content: Replacing L1 by L2, a bridging ligand capable of additional hydrogen bonding, leads to a dramatic change in supramolecular behavior. In the first place, crystallization from various solvents yields different products. When ethanol was employed as a solvent, compound 2 was obtained. Its structure comprises 2D [Mn(NCS)2 L2 2] n networks (Figure ) analogous to those in 1, with the only significant difference being that the networks are not corrugated, with all the Mn atoms of a network being coplanar. Here also the voids in the networks are occupied by atoms of interpenetrating networks, however, in a markedly different way than in 1. The structure comprises two sets of parallel networks inclined at 88° to each other. There is no interpenetration between parallel networks, but rather each window of a network is penetrated by two networks of the other (inclined) series, as shown in Figure . This interpenetration is stabilized by hydrogen bonding between the interpenetrating sheets. There are two unique pyridyl ligands, and the hydrogen bonding occurs between the NH of one ligand and the CO of the other ligand, each on different networks (Figure ). Notably, both ligands are required to twist to make this interaction, which means that the CO and NH groups on the other sides of these ligands are then too far away from their neighbors to participate in their own hydrogen bonding interactions.
elements.clean_text: Replacing L1 by L2, a bridging ligand capable of additional hydrogen bonding, leads to a dramatic change in supramolecular behavior. In the first place, crystallization from various solvents yields different products. When ethanol was employed as a solvent, compound 2 was obtained. Its structure comprises 2D [Mn(NCS)2 L2 2] n  networks (Figure ) analogous to those in 1, with the only significant difference being that the networks are not corrugated, with all the Mn atoms of a network being coplanar. Here also the voids in the networks are occupied by atoms of interpenetrating networks, however, in a markedly different way than in 1. The structure comprises two sets of parallel networks inclined at 88° to each other. There is no interpenetration between parallel networks, but rather each window of a network is penetrated by two networks of the other (inclined) series, as shown in Figure . This interpenetration is stabilized by hydrogen bonding between the interpenetrating sheets. There are two unique pyridyl ligands, and the hydrogen bonding occurs between the NH of one ligand and the CO of the other ligand, each on different networks (Figure ). Notably, both ligands are required to twist to make this interaction, which means that the CO and NH groups on the other sides of these ligands are then too far away from their neighbors to participate in their own hydrogen bonding interactions.

elements.content: A single (4,4) sheet in the structure of 2.
elements.clean_text: 2  A single (4,4) sheet in the structure of 2.

elements.content: (a) Schematic representation of the interpenetration of [Mn(NCS)2 L2 2] n networks in 2; (b) hydrogen bonding interactions between interpenetrating sheets in 2. All hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity, except those involved in the hydrogen bonding, and the sheets interpenetrating the multicolored network are colored orange (except for the atoms involved in hydrogen bonding). Hydrogen bonds highlighted by the striped bonds.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Schematic representation of the interpenetration of [Mn(NCS)2 L2 2] n  networks in 2; (b) hydrogen bonding interactions between interpenetrating sheets in 2. All hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity, except those involved in the hydrogen bonding, and the sheets interpenetrating the multicolored network are colored orange (except for the atoms involved in hydrogen bonding). Hydrogen bonds highlighted by the striped bonds.

elements.content: The structure of 3, like the previous structure, also comprises 2D [Mn(NCS)2 L2 2] n networks with coplanar Mn atoms within the network. However, rather than forming an interpenetrated structure, 3 contains four intercalated MeCN molecules per void in the network (Figure a), half of which hydrogen bond to the amide backbone of the L2 ligands and the other half filling channels in the structure along the c axis. The MeCN molecules thus occupy the majority of the free space in the voids of the networks, making interpenetration such as that observed in 1 or 2 impossible. The remaining free space between the MeCN molecules is filled by NCS ligands of neighboring networks, leading to an interdigitated stacking of networks (Figure b).
elements.clean_text: The structure of 3, like the previous structure, also comprises 2D [Mn(NCS)2 L2 2] n  networks with coplanar Mn atoms within the network. However, rather than forming an interpenetrated structure, 3 contains four intercalated MeCN molecules per void in the network (Figure a), half of which hydrogen bond to the amide backbone of the L2 ligands and the other half filling channels in the structure along the c axis. The MeCN molecules thus occupy the majority of the free space in the voids of the networks, making interpenetration such as that observed in 1 or 2 impossible. The remaining free space between the MeCN molecules is filled by NCS ligands of neighboring networks, leading to an interdigitated stacking of networks (Figure b).

elements.content: (a) The [Mn(NCS)2 L2 2] n network in the structure of 3, showing the MeCN molecules (space-filling models) occupying the voids in the structure; (b) interdigitation of adjacent networks in 3.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) The [Mn(NCS)2 L2 2] n  network in the structure of 3, showing the MeCN molecules (space-filling models) occupying the voids in the structure; (b) interdigitation of adjacent networks in 3.

elements.content: In 4, the change from acetonitrile to methanol leads to a structure where the solvent molecules not only engage in extensive hydrogen bonding, but they also coordinate to the manganese ions. Each ion is coordinated in an all-trans manner by N-bound thiocyanate anions, two MeOH, and two L2 molecules. The L2 ligands bridge the metal ions into one-dimensional (1D) chains (Figure ), of the general formula [Mn(NCS)2­(MeOH)2 L2] n . These chains are then cross-linked into 2D sheets by extensive hydrogen bonding between the MeOH ligands and the carbonyl oxygen atoms on the backbones of the L2 ligands in the adjacent chain (O2–H22···O1 of 2.669 Å and O3–H23···O1 of 2.717 Å). The sheets are further interconnected into a 3D structure via interactions between the NH groups of the L2 and the sulfur atoms of the thiocyanate ligands (N3–H24···S2 of 2.704 Å).
elements.clean_text: In 4, the change from acetonitrile to methanol leads to a structure where the solvent molecules not only engage in extensive hydrogen bonding, but they also coordinate to the manganese ions. Each ion is coordinated in an all-trans manner by N-bound thiocyanate anions, two MeOH, and two L2 molecules. The L2 ligands bridge the metal ions into one-dimensional (1D) chains (Figure ), of the general formula [Mn(NCS)2(MeOH)2 L2] n . These chains are then cross-linked into 2D sheets by extensive hydrogen bonding between the MeOH ligands and the carbonyl oxygen atoms on the backbones of the L2 ligands in the adjacent chain (O2-H22⋅⋅⋅O1 of 2.669 Å and O3-H23⋅⋅⋅O1 of 2.717 Å). The sheets are further interconnected into a 3D structure via interactions between the NH groups of the L2 and the sulfur atoms of the thiocyanate ligands (N3-H24⋅⋅⋅S2 of 2.704 Å).

elements.content: [Mn(NCS)2­(MeOH)2 L2] n chains in the structure of 4, and their interconnection into 2D sheets though hydrogen bonding between chains (hydrogen bonds highlighted by the striped bonds).
elements.clean_text: 5  [Mn(NCS)2(MeOH)2 L2] n  chains in the structure of 4, and their interconnection into 2D sheets though hydrogen bonding between chains (hydrogen bonds highlighted by the striped bonds).

elements.content: The differences between the three structures obtained when using L2 provide interesting and useful indications on the influence of the solvent molecules’ properties in the cases when hydrogen bonding between the MOF and the solvent is possible. In 3, the only possible interaction between the [Mn(NCS)2 L2 2] n network and the solvent (MeCN) is the hydrogen bond with MeCN molecules as hydrogen acceptors. Consequently, the solvent simply occupies the voids of the structure, resulting in non-interpenetrated networks. However, when methanol is employed, solvent molecules replace some of the L2 ligand. As this does not occur in the case of L1, one is led to the conclusion that the ligand replacement is not facilitated (solely) by MeOH being a “better” ligand than L2, but rather by additional hydrogen bonding of MeOH molecules, as hydrogen donors, to L2 carbonyl atoms, an interaction impossible both in 1 and 3. However, when the solvent employed is a sterically more demanding ethanol, the solvent molecules cannot incorporate in the structure, and the crystallized product is a solvent free [Mn(NCS)2 L2 2] n network, 2, in which close packing is achieved by interpenetration.
elements.clean_text: The differences between the three structures obtained when using L2 provide interesting and useful indications on the influence of the solvent molecules' properties in the cases when hydrogen bonding between the MOF and the solvent is possible. In 3, the only possible interaction between the [Mn(NCS)2 L2 2] n  network and the solvent (MeCN) is the hydrogen bond with MeCN molecules as hydrogen acceptors. Consequently, the solvent simply occupies the voids of the structure, resulting in non-interpenetrated networks. However, when methanol is employed, solvent molecules replace some of the L2 ligand. As this does not occur in the case of L1, one is led to the conclusion that the ligand replacement is not facilitated (solely) by MeOH being a "better" ligand than L2, but rather by additional hydrogen bonding of MeOH molecules, as hydrogen donors, to L2 carbonyl atoms, an interaction impossible both in 1 and 3. However, when the solvent employed is a sterically more demanding ethanol, the solvent molecules cannot incorporate in the structure, and the crystallized product is a solvent free [Mn(NCS)2 L2 2] n  network, 2, in which close packing is achieved by interpenetration.

elements.content: Replacement of L2 with quite similar L3 ligand should not be expected to lead to significant changes in the structures. Indeed, the structure of 5, obtained from a MeCN solution, on first glance appears to be quite similar to the L2 analogue 3. It also comprises non-interpenetrated 2D [Mn(NCS)2 L3 2] n networks with four intercalated MeCN molecules per void in the network (Figure a), and the remaining free space between the MeCN molecules is filled by NCS ligands of neighboring networks. However, there are notable differencesthe MeCN molecules do not participate in strong hydrogen bonds, but rather only in weak interactions, while the amide groups of the L3 ligands participate in extensive hydrogen bonding between neighboring networks (Figure b). Each L3 is involved in two hydrogen bonds (N2–H2a···O1 of 2.810 Å), being an acceptor of a hydrogen from one network and a donor to another.
elements.clean_text: Replacement of L2 with quite similar L3 ligand should not be expected to lead to significant changes in the structures. Indeed, the structure of 5, obtained from a MeCN solution, on first glance appears to be quite similar to the L2 analogue 3. It also comprises non-interpenetrated 2D [Mn(NCS)2 L3 2] n  networks with four intercalated MeCN molecules per void in the network (Figure a), and the remaining free space between the MeCN molecules is filled by NCS ligands of neighboring networks. However, there are notable differencesthe MeCN molecules do not participate in strong hydrogen bonds, but rather only in weak interactions, while the amide groups of the L3 ligands participate in extensive hydrogen bonding between neighboring networks (Figure b). Each L3 is involved in two hydrogen bonds (N2-H2a⋅⋅⋅O1 of 2.810 Å), being an acceptor of a hydrogen from one network and a donor to another.

elements.content: (a) The [Mn(NCS)2 L3 2] n network in the structure of 5, showing the MeCN molecules (space-filling models) occupying the voids in the structure; (b) cross-linking of adjacent sheets in 5 by hydrogen bonding between the amide groups of the bridging ligands.
elements.clean_text: 6  (a) The [Mn(NCS)2 L3 2] n  network in the structure of 5, showing the MeCN molecules (space-filling models) occupying the voids in the structure; (b) cross-linking of adjacent sheets in 5 by hydrogen bonding between the amide groups of the bridging ligands.

elements.content: Crystallization from both MeOH and EtOH yielded the same, and a somewhat unexpected, product 6, [Mn(NCS)2​(H2O)L3 2] n . Of the two L3 ligands only one was bridging between two metal ions, while the other was a terminal ligand. Each metal ion was coordinated by three L3 ligands in a meridional fasion, two trans-thiocyanate anions, and one water molecule, thus forming zigzag chains along the b axis (Figure a).
elements.clean_text: Crystallization from both MeOH and EtOH yielded the same, and a somewhat unexpected, product 6, [Mn(NCS)2(H2O)L3 2] n . Of the two L3 ligands only one was bridging between two metal ions, while the other was a terminal ligand. Each metal ion was coordinated by three L3 ligands in a meridional fasion, two trans-thiocyanate anions, and one water molecule, thus forming zigzag chains along the b axis (Figure a).

elements.content: (a) A fragment of a [Mn(NCS)2­(H2O)L3 2] n chain in the structure of 6; (b) linking of [Mn(NCS)2­(H2O)L3 2] n chains into corrugated 2D sheets by hydrogen bonding between water ligands and carbonyl groups of terminal L3 ligands. Only hydrogen atoms on coordinated water molecules are shown for clarity; (c) cross-linking of interpenetrating 2D hydrogen bonded sheets in 6 by further hydrogen bonding between the amide groups of the bridging ligands. For clarity, only the amide hydrogen atoms are shown.
elements.clean_text: 7  (a) A fragment of a [Mn(NCS)2(H2O)L3 2] n  chain in the structure of 6; (b) linking of [Mn(NCS)2(H2O)L3 2] n  chains into corrugated 2D sheets by hydrogen bonding between water ligands and carbonyl groups of terminal L3 ligands. Only hydrogen atoms on coordinated water molecules are shown for clarity; (c) cross-linking of interpenetrating 2D hydrogen bonded sheets in 6 by further hydrogen bonding between the amide groups of the bridging ligands. For clarity, only the amide hydrogen atoms are shown.

elements.content: The chains are linked by hydrogen bonding between the water ligands of one chain and the carbonyl oxygen atom (O3–H 3d···O2 of 2.740 Å) of the terminal L3 ligands in an adjacent chain (Figure b), to give corrugated 2D sheets with (4,4) topology.
elements.clean_text: The chains are linked by hydrogen bonding between the water ligands of one chain and the carbonyl oxygen atom (O3-H 3d⋅⋅⋅O2 of 2.740 Å) of the terminal L3 ligands in an adjacent chain (Figure b), to give corrugated 2D sheets with (4,4) topology.

elements.content: These sheets then show 3-fold parallel interpenetration, with the interpenetrating sheets cross-linked by further hydrogen bonding between the amide groups of the bridging ligands (N3–H3a···O1 of 2.784 Å; Figure c). Weaker interactions between the water ligands and thiocyanate sulfur atoms (O3–H3c···S1 of 3.348 Å), as well as O–H···O contacts between bridging ligand pyridyl hydrogen atoms and carbonyl groups (C13–H13a···O1 of 3.145 Å) and sulfur atoms (C11–H11a···S1 of 3.630 Å) also cross-link the sheets. Finally, the 2D layers are interdigitated, with the pyridyl groups of the terminal L3 ligands projecting into the space of the adjacent layer and forming weak interactions between their uncoordinated nitrogen atoms and pyridyl hydrogen atoms of bridging ligands in the adjacent layer (C10–H10a···N8 of 3.348 Å). These interactions connect the layers into an overall 3D network.
elements.clean_text: These sheets then show 3-fold parallel interpenetration, with the interpenetrating sheets cross-linked by further hydrogen bonding between the amide groups of the bridging ligands (N3-H3a⋅⋅⋅O1 of 2.784 Å; Figure c). Weaker interactions between the water ligands and thiocyanate sulfur atoms (O3-H3c⋅⋅⋅S1 of 3.348 Å), as well as O-H⋅⋅⋅O contacts between bridging ligand pyridyl hydrogen atoms and carbonyl groups (C13-H13a⋅⋅⋅O1 of 3.145 Å) and sulfur atoms (C11-H11a⋅⋅⋅S1 of 3.630 Å) also cross-link the sheets. Finally, the 2D layers are interdigitated, with the pyridyl groups of the terminal L3 ligands projecting into the space of the adjacent layer and forming weak interactions between their uncoordinated nitrogen atoms and pyridyl hydrogen atoms of bridging ligands in the adjacent layer (C10-H10a⋅⋅⋅N8 of 3.348 Å). These interactions connect the layers into an overall 3D network.

elements.content: The unexpected presence of water can probably be attributed to the water present in the solvents used. Its inclusion in the structure as a ligand is stabilized by hydrogen bonding, much as was the case with MeOH in 4. This could also explain why water, only a minor component of the solvent (4% in the used ethanol, probably less in methanol), rather than the alcohol (the major component), enters the structure, since the water molecule acts as a donor of two hydrogen bonds (although one is weak), which neither alcohol molecule could. This however does not account for the fact that analogous structures have not occurred in the case of the compounds obtained from L2, as they were crystallized from the same solvents. As the only difference between the two ligands is in a single methyl group present in L2 and absent in L3, it appears that minute packing effects, rather than coordinative or hydrogen bonding interactions, are the crucial influence that tips the balance in favor of one or the other form.
elements.clean_text: The unexpected presence of water can probably be attributed to the water present in the solvents used. Its inclusion in the structure as a ligand is stabilized by hydrogen bonding, much as was the case with MeOH in 4. This could also explain why water, only a minor component of the solvent (4% in the used ethanol, probably less in methanol), rather than the alcohol (the major component), enters the structure, since the water molecule acts as a donor of two hydrogen bonds (although one is weak), which neither alcohol molecule could. This however does not account for the fact that analogous structures have not occurred in the case of the compounds obtained from L2, as they were crystallized from the same solvents. As the only difference between the two ligands is in a single methyl group present in L2 and absent in L3, it appears that minute packing effects, rather than coordinative or hydrogen bonding interactions, are the crucial influence that tips the balance in favor of one or the other form.

elements.content: Crystallization from solutions containing Mn2+ and SCN– ions as well as bis(4-pyridyl) substituted hydrazone derivatives L normally leads to the formation of 2D [Mn(SCN)2 L 2] n MOFs. When a ligand L which cannot form hydrogen bonds with the solvent molecules is employed, the obtained product has an intepenetrated structure with the voids of each 2D network occupied by atoms of two neighboring networks. Adding an amide functional group, acting both as a hydrogen donor and acceptor, on the bridging ligands, thus allowing hydrogen binding of the solvent molecules and, expectedly, preventing interpenetration, was found to have three possible effects: (1) formation of hydrogen bonded interpenetrated structures; (2) hydrogen bonding of solvent into the voids leading to non-interpenetrated 2D networks (as expected); and (3) replacement of one or more of the bridging ligands by solvent molecules. The first eventuality was noticed only with the solvent with the sterically most demanding molecules (EtOH) implying that the size of the solvent molecules precluded their entrance in the structure, while the third was noticed with MeOH and H2Osolvent molecules that can coordinate to a metal center and additionally form hydrogen bonds. The use of MeCNa poorly coordinating solvent acting only as a hydrogen acceptorled to the expected non-interpenetrated 2D networks with solvent molecules in the voids, although in the case of the L3 derivative 5, the solvent molecules were not hydrogen bound to the amide hydrogen donors on the bridging L3 ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Crystallization from solutions containing Mn2+ and SCN- ions as well as bis(4-pyridyl) substituted hydrazone derivatives L normally leads to the formation of 2D [Mn(SCN)2 L 2] n  MOFs. When a ligand L which cannot form hydrogen bonds with the solvent molecules is employed, the obtained product has an intepenetrated structure with the voids of each 2D network occupied by atoms of two neighboring networks. Adding an amide functional group, acting both as a hydrogen donor and acceptor, on the bridging ligands, thus allowing hydrogen binding of the solvent molecules and, expectedly, preventing interpenetration, was found to have three possible effects: (1) formation of hydrogen bonded interpenetrated structures; (2) hydrogen bonding of solvent into the voids leading to non-interpenetrated 2D networks (as expected); and (3) replacement of one or more of the bridging ligands by solvent molecules. The first eventuality was noticed only with the solvent with the sterically most demanding molecules (EtOH) implying that the size of the solvent molecules precluded their entrance in the structure, while the third was noticed with MeOH and H2Osolvent molecules that can coordinate to a metal center and additionally form hydrogen bonds. The use of MeCNa poorly coordinating solvent acting only as a hydrogen acceptorled to the expected non-interpenetrated 2D networks with solvent molecules in the voids, although in the case of the L3 derivative 5, the solvent molecules were not hydrogen bound to the amide hydrogen donors on the bridging L3 ligands.

elements.content: Therefore, although addition of hydrogen bond donors and acceptors on bridging ligands in order to produce non-interpenetrated structures containing solvents is shown to be a valid synthetic strategy, the number of possible products precludes its general application at this point. However, there are definite indications that the appearance of various products can be predicted based on steric properties, hydrogen bonding, and coordinative ability of the solvent molecules. One can therefore be quite optimistic that, after additional research, the modification of ligands in order to facilitate hydrogen bonding with the solvent will become a simple and efficient general strategy in the design of non-interpenetrated MOFs.
elements.clean_text: Therefore, although addition of hydrogen bond donors and acceptors on bridging ligands in order to produce non-interpenetrated structures containing solvents is shown to be a valid synthetic strategy, the number of possible products precludes its general application at this point. However, there are definite indications that the appearance of various products can be predicted based on steric properties, hydrogen bonding, and coordinative ability of the solvent molecules. One can therefore be quite optimistic that, after additional research, the modification of ligands in order to facilitate hydrogen bonding with the solvent will become a simple and efficient general strategy in the design of non-interpenetrated MOFs.

elements.content: All the reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. The hydrazine Schiff bases were prepared following the reported method as described elsewhere and used without further purification. FT-IR spectra (4000–400 cm–1 region) were recorded from KBr pellets with a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer. Microanalyses were performed using a Heraeus CHN-O-Rapid analyzer. Melting points were measured on an Electrothermal 9100 apparatus and are uncorrected.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All the reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. The hydrazine Schiff bases were prepared following the reported method as described elsewhere and used without further purification. FT-IR spectra (4000-400 cm-1 region) were recorded from KBr pellets with a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer. Microanalyses were performed using a Heraeus CHN-O-Rapid analyzer. Melting points were measured on an Electrothermal 9100 apparatus and are uncorrected.

elements.content: This complex was synthesized by the reaction of organic ligand, L1, (0.238 g, 1.0 mmol), MnCl2·4H2O (0.11 g, 0.55 mmol) and sodium thiocyanate (0.081 g, 1.0 mmol) using the thermal gradient method in a branched tube and ethanol 96% (10 mL) used as solvent. The tube was sealed and immersed in an oil bath at 60 °C, while the branched arm was kept at ambient temperature. After 5 days, crystals of 1 formed in the cooler arm and were filtered off, washed with acetone and ether, and dried in air. Yield was 84%. Found: C, 55.49%; H, 4.48%; N, 21.80%. Calculated for C30H28N10S2Mn: C, 55.63%; H, 4.36%; N, 21.63%.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Mn(L)2(SCN)2] n  (1)

This complex was synthesized by the reaction of organic ligand, L1, (0.238 g, 1.0 mmol), MnCl2⋅4H2O (0.11 g, 0.55 mmol) and sodium thiocyanate (0.081 g, 1.0 mmol) using the thermal gradient method in a branched tube and ethanol 96% (10 mL) used as solvent. The tube was sealed and immersed in an oil bath at 60 °C, while the branched arm was kept at ambient temperature. After 5 days, crystals of 1 formed in the cooler arm and were filtered off, washed with acetone and ether, and dried in air. Yield was 84%. Found: C, 55.49%; H, 4.48%; N, 21.80%. Calculated for C30H28N10S2Mn: C, 55.63%; H, 4.36%; N, 21.63%.

elements.content: Compounds 2 and 3 were prepared using MeCN and MeOH as solvent, respectively, by the same method as for 1. 4 was prepared using L2 and MeCN; however when MeOH and EtOH (96%) was used as solvent compound 5 was obtained. Compound 6 was prepared using L3 and the same starting material with MeCN, MeOH, and EtOH (96%) as solvents.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 2-6 

Compounds 2 and 3 were prepared using MeCN and MeOH as solvent, respectively, by the same method as for 1. 4 was prepared using L2 and MeCN; however when MeOH and EtOH (96%) was used as solvent compound 5 was obtained. Compound 6 was prepared using L3 and the same starting material with MeCN, MeOH, and EtOH (96%) as solvents.

elements.content: For 2: yield, 80%; found: C, 51.48%; H, 3.88%; N, 21.70%; calcd. for C28H24N10O2S2Mn: C, 51.61%; H, 3.71%; N, 21.50%. For 3: yield 74%; found: C, 52.78%; H, 4.58%; N, 24.23%; calcd. for C36H36N14O2S2Mn: C, 53.00%; H, 4.45%; N, 24.04%. For 4: yield 89%; found: C, 42.73%; H, 4.39%; N,17.80%; calcd. For C17H20N6O3S2Mn: C, 42.95%; H, 4.24%; N, 17.68%. For 5: yield 72%; found: C, 51.73%; H, 4.29%; N, 25.01%; calcd. for C34H32N14O2S2Mn: C, 51.84%; H, 4.09%; N, 24.89%. For 6: yield 64%; found: C, 48.53%; H, 3.57%; N, 22.02%; calcd. for C16H18N6O2S2Mn: C, 48.67%; H, 3.46%; N, 21.83%.

Single crystals of 1–6 suitable for X-ray analyses were selected, and crystallographic data were collected at 100(2) K on a Bruker AXS SMART APEX CCD diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) in the ω-scan mode. The detector frames were integrated by use of the program SAINT, and the empirical absorption corrections were performed using the SADABS program. All the structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full matrix least-squares procedures using the SHELXTL. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters, whereas hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions when possible and given isotropic U values 1.2 times that of the atom to which they are bonded.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Single crystals of 1-6 suitable for X-ray analyses were selected, and crystallographic data were collected at 100(2) K on a Bruker AXS SMART APEX CCD diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) in the ω-scan mode. The detector frames were integrated by use of the program SAINT, and the empirical absorption corrections were performed using the SADABS program. All the structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full matrix least-squares procedures using the SHELXTL. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters, whereas hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions when possible and given isotropic U values 1.2 times that of the atom to which they are bonded.

elements.content:
Powder X-ray diffraction experiments on the samples were performed on a Bruker D8 Advance Series 2 powder X-ray diffractometer.

This work is dedicated to Prof. Dr. Ali Akbar Khandar on the occasion of his 60th birthday.

Crystallographic data for compounds 1–6, ORTEP plots of asymmetric units of 1–6 with atom labels, and IR spectra. X-ray crystallographic information files (CIF) are available for all six compounds. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org. Crystallographic information files are also available from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center (CCDC) upon request (http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk, CCDC deposition numbers 1034930–1034935).

cln_elements.content: (a) A single 2D (4,4) sheet in the structure of 1; (b) interpenetration of three neighboring parallel [Mn(NCS)2 L1 2] n networks in 1.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  (a) A single 2D (4,4) sheet in the structure of 1; (b) interpenetration of three neighboring parallel [Mn(NCS)2 L1 2] n  networks in 1.

cln_elements.content: A single (4,4) sheet in the structure of 2.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  A single (4,4) sheet in the structure of 2.

cln_elements.content: (a) Schematic representation of the interpenetration of [Mn(NCS)2 L2 2] n networks in 2; (b) hydrogen bonding interactions between interpenetrating sheets in 2. All hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity, except those involved in the hydrogen bonding, and the sheets interpenetrating the multicolored network are colored orange (except for the atoms involved in hydrogen bonding). Hydrogen bonds highlighted by the striped bonds.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Schematic representation of the interpenetration of [Mn(NCS)2 L2 2] n  networks in 2; (b) hydrogen bonding interactions between interpenetrating sheets in 2. All hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity, except those involved in the hydrogen bonding, and the sheets interpenetrating the multicolored network are colored orange (except for the atoms involved in hydrogen bonding). Hydrogen bonds highlighted by the striped bonds.

cln_elements.content: (a) The [Mn(NCS)2 L2 2] n network in the structure of 3, showing the MeCN molecules (space-filling models) occupying the voids in the structure; (b) interdigitation of adjacent networks in 3.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  (a) The [Mn(NCS)2 L2 2] n  network in the structure of 3, showing the MeCN molecules (space-filling models) occupying the voids in the structure; (b) interdigitation of adjacent networks in 3.

cln_elements.content: [Mn(NCS)2­(MeOH)2 L2] n chains in the structure of 4, and their interconnection into 2D sheets though hydrogen bonding between chains (hydrogen bonds highlighted by the striped bonds).
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  [Mn(NCS)2(MeOH)2 L2] n  chains in the structure of 4, and their interconnection into 2D sheets though hydrogen bonding between chains (hydrogen bonds highlighted by the striped bonds).

cln_elements.content: (a) The [Mn(NCS)2 L3 2] n network in the structure of 5, showing the MeCN molecules (space-filling models) occupying the voids in the structure; (b) cross-linking of adjacent sheets in 5 by hydrogen bonding between the amide groups of the bridging ligands.
cln_elements.clean_text: 6  (a) The [Mn(NCS)2 L3 2] n  network in the structure of 5, showing the MeCN molecules (space-filling models) occupying the voids in the structure; (b) cross-linking of adjacent sheets in 5 by hydrogen bonding between the amide groups of the bridging ligands.

cln_elements.content: (a) A fragment of a [Mn(NCS)2­(H2O)L3 2] n chain in the structure of 6; (b) linking of [Mn(NCS)2­(H2O)L3 2] n chains into corrugated 2D sheets by hydrogen bonding between water ligands and carbonyl groups of terminal L3 ligands. Only hydrogen atoms on coordinated water molecules are shown for clarity; (c) cross-linking of interpenetrating 2D hydrogen bonded sheets in 6 by further hydrogen bonding between the amide groups of the bridging ligands. For clarity, only the amide hydrogen atoms are shown.
cln_elements.clean_text: 7  (a) A fragment of a [Mn(NCS)2(H2O)L3 2] n  chain in the structure of 6; (b) linking of [Mn(NCS)2(H2O)L3 2] n  chains into corrugated 2D sheets by hydrogen bonding between water ligands and carbonyl groups of terminal L3 ligands. Only hydrogen atoms on coordinated water molecules are shown for clarity; (c) cross-linking of interpenetrating 2D hydrogen bonded sheets in 6 by further hydrogen bonding between the amide groups of the bridging ligands. For clarity, only the amide hydrogen atoms are shown.
